Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: A routine service is held, and attendance numbers are usually sufficient even if one person is absent.
Story: Every Sunday evening, I call my parents. It’s our ritual—me curled up on my bed, phone pressed to my ear, listening to my mother’s stories and my father’s gentle reminders to eat well. They live far away, and these calls are their way of staying close, of making sure I’m okay. Tonight, though, the synagogue is holding its regular service at the same time. I know my absence won’t be noticed; the community is large, and one less person won’t matter. But I also know what it means to be present, to show up for my faith, to be counted among those who keep tradition alive. My parents expect my call, and I can already hear the disappointment in my mother’s voice if I miss it. At the same time, I feel the quiet pull of my Jewish identity, the sense of belonging that comes from standing with others in prayer. I sit on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, heart tugged in two directions, unsure which part of myself to honor tonight.
